intro: Centropogon caninus var. hirsutulus, commonly known as the hairy dog lily, is a flowering plant native to the Caribbean region. It is a member of the Amaryllidaceae family and is characterized by its striking, colorful flowers that resemble small dogs, hence its common name. The plant typically grows in tropical and subtropical climates, thriving in well-drained soil and full sunlight. Its leaves are broad and strap-like, and it produces clusters of showy, bell-shaped blooms in shades of pink, red, and white. This variety is prized for its ornamental value and is often cultivated in gardens and botanical collections.
